metadata.case_name: State of U.P. v. Respondents (Col. Sujan Singh and another)

facts.text: Respondents prosecuted in court of Special Judge, Anti-Corruption (East), U.P., Lucknow, after obtaining sanction of Central Government under s.197 CrPC for offence under s.6(1)(a) Prevention of Corruption Act, 1947.
Objection taken by respondents that sanctioning authority did not apply mind properly when sanction granted.
On representation by Col. Sujan Singh (one accused) for reconsideration, Deputy Secretary in Home Department reconsidered and noted that sanction accorded earlier on insufficient data.
Col. Sujan Singh filed petition before Special Judge to summon concerned record of Home Department to substantiate assertion.
Secretary, Ministry of Home Affairs claimed privilege on ground production of record containing Deputy Secretary's notings would not be in interests of State.
Special Judge rejected claim of privilege; High Court in Criminal Revision No. 251 of 1962 (judgment dated November 23, 1962) rejected claim in revision.
Certified copy of High Court judgment delivered to appellant on December 5, 1962.
Appellant filed petition in High Court on December 19, 1962 for certificate under Art.134(1)(c) Constitution.
High Court on February 18, 1963 held order interlocutory, petition not maintainable under Art.134(1)(c).
Appellant filed special leave petition in Supreme Court on April 16, 1963.
Notice of dispatch of records served on counsel for respondents on November 4, 1963.
Respondents received notice granting special leave on January 16, 1964.
Respondents filed appearance on February 11, 1964 and statement of case on February 18, 1964.
Appellant filed application to excuse 42 days delay in special leave petition.

legal_issues.text: Whether the appeal is barred by limitation as special leave petition filed beyond 90 days from High Court judgment dated November 23, 1962.
Whether High Court order dated November 23, 1962 rejecting privilege claim is a 'final order' under Art.134(1)(c) Constitution.
Whether delay in filing special leave petition should be excused based on legal advice that limitation runs from High Court refusal of certificate on February 18, 1963.

petitioner_arguments.text: Special leave granted on May 10, 1963; respondents did not object to limitation till late stage.
High Court order dated November 23, 1962 is final order under Art.134(1)(c); application for certificate maintainable.
Law Officer advised application under Art.134(1)(c) first; acted bona fide believing limitation from February 18, 1963 per Supreme Court Rules Order XXI r.2.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Supreme Court Rules Order XXI r.2

respondent_arguments.text: Notice of dispatch served on counsel November 4, 1963; appearance and statement filed beyond time under High Court Rules Ch.V r.41(c) r.2.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: Allahabad High Court Rules Ch.V r.41(c) r.2

respondent_arguments.text: No sufficient reason to excuse delay in special leave petition; application for certificate not maintainable.

court_reasoning.text: Excused respondents' delay in appearance and statement as not due to negligence, no prejudice to appellant.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Delay only procedural, within time from personal service.

court_reasoning.text: Special leave petition out of time by 42 days as limitation from November 23, 1962 (expires March 5, 1963); High Court certificate application not maintainable as order interlocutory, not final under Art.134(1)(c).
court_reasoning.key_observation: Order merely procedural for production of document, does not bind rights of parties; cites Seth Premchand Satramdas v. State of Bihar.

court_reasoning.text: Appellant failed to disclose in affidavit ground of High Court refusal per Supreme Court Rules Order XXI r.2; wrong legal advice not sufficient to excuse delay.
court_reasoning.key_observation: No justification for 42-day delay despite High Court order on February 18, 1963.

holdings.text: High Court order dated November 23, 1962 not final order under Art.134(1)(c); certificate application not maintainable.
Delay in special leave petition not excused; appeal barred by limitation.

precedents_cited.case_name: Seth Premchand Satramdas v. State of Bihar
precedents_cited.relevance: Definition of 'final order': order must bind or affect rights of parties of its own force.

statutes_cited.name: Evidence Act
statutes_cited.relevance: Basis for privilege claim by Union Government

statutes_cited.name: Constitution of India
statutes_cited.relevance: Certificate for appeal to Supreme Court from High Court criminal orders

statutes_cited.name: Supreme Court Rules
statutes_cited.relevance: Requirements for special leave petition when certificate refused; computation of limitation

statutes_cited.name: Allahabad High Court Rules
statutes_cited.relevance: Service of notice on advocate deemed sufficient

outcome.summary: Appeal dismissed as barred by limitation; delay in special leave petition not condoned. Respondents' delay in appearance condoned.

key_quotes.text: "It seems to us that the order appealed against in this case cannot be regarded as a final order, because it does not of its own force bind or affect the rights of the parties."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Definition of final order from precedent applied to hold High Court order interlocutory.

key_quotes.text: "The said order is only an interlocutory order pending the proceedings. It does not purport to decide the rights of the parties."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Court's holding on character of the order under appeal.

key_quotes.text: "So the appeal is clearly barred by limitation and should be dismissed."
key_quotes.speaker: court
